intro: Pimpinella ternata, commonly known as wild cumin or three-lobed cow-wheat, is a flowering plant belonging to the Apiaceae family. It is characterized by its trifoliate leaves and small, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in umbels. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is found in temperate regions of Europe and Asia. Its seeds are used in traditional medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. Pimpinella ternata is also a host plant for certain butterfly species, contributing to its ecological significance.
